course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Understanding Comparative Politics
course.description: Compares the political systems of democratic, socialist and authoritarian regimes, by looking at Canada/U.S., China/Former Soviet Union, and Egypt. Course teaches the comparative method and policy analysis. Key issues include state formation, political leadership, political culture, political participation, political conflict, political institutions, and political processes and policy making.

reviews.author: hihihi
reviews.title: good course by a knowledgeable teacher with moderate workload
reviews.comment_content: Good content, syllabus adequately covers all basic topic in comparative politics.  Can help you understand more about the political scene around the world.  Prof also added some new content according to happenings at that time and it was interesting
reviews.comment_teaching: Good and very kind teacher, very willing to help students, no attendance taking but I feel motivated to attend most lessons.  A lot of real world examples in the course.
reviews.comment_grading: you can certainly get good grade if you are interested in the course and is willing to study
reviews.comment_workload: Work load not bad, one presentation + one mid term + one final essay.  Mid term is just like CE exam, marks given if you mentioned the key point so not very difficult but really need to recite and understand.  Presentation is not very difficult because you can choose your own topic and do it in your own way.  Also can choose own topic for final essay, but i think it is a little difficult to do a good job.  In general workload not very light but adequate for a 3000 lvl course

reviews.author: AceOfSpades
reviews.title: Don't miss out on this course before you finally regret it.
reviews.comment_content:
Part I: Doing Comparative Politics
- Orientation
- Comparative Approaches and Methods

Part II: Comparing Political Regimes
- Democracy
- Economic Explanations
- Cultural Explanations
- Dictatorship and Political Consequences

Part III: Comparative Political Actors
- Politcial Parties
- Interest Groups

Part IV: Comparing Political Institutions
- Government Systems
- Democratic Systems and Political Consequences
- Electoral Systems and Political Consequences
reviews.comment_teaching:
As I first joined the course, I was worried I wouldn't manage all the essays and group project as a final year student. But now? I don't think I will ever regret it.

This is one of the few courses maintaining its sound quality despite going into online mode. The course content is juicy and pragmatic, and it really helps you understand how the world works. Whether you are travelling to other country or not, the knowledge you acquired from this course will certainly also help you in real life.

James is a down-to-earth professor, and he is also very knowledgeable outside of politics. He explains the theories and uses both theortical and real-life examples to make sure we understand them clearly. His TA, Riley, is also responsive. Concise and detailed feedback is provided for every assignment. I hardly feel any stress or tension in participating in this course's lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean is usually 80% to 90% for each assignment listed here.

Poster and Video Description (group-based): 20%
Peer Review (group-based): 5%
Take-home Essays (x2): 60%, 30% each
MC Quizzes (x3): 15%, 5% each

Participation Bonus: A maximum of 5 points will be awarded to students who contribute actively to class discussions.

Textbook:
William Roberts Clark, Matt Golder & Sona Nadenichek Golderâ€™s (2019) Foundations of Comparative Politics

Seriously though, you don't need to buy any. It's perfectly fine as long as you attend the lecture and read through all lecture materials.
reviews.comment_workload:
I'd say the workload depends on how well you've learnt from this course.

All multiple choice quizzes are open-book, and you are given enough time to revise before starting the quiz on your own.

As for the essays, you are tasked to write in 1000 - 1200 words within 5 - 7 days.

If you can understand anything that is taught in the course, you should be able to handle the assignments as well.

2. Apply concepts and theories in discussing issues in comparative politics.
3. Exercise independent and critical judgments in the study of politics.

reviews.author: Rexhere1
reviews.title: A great course for basics in political science
reviews.comment_content: Mainly the content comes from the textbook and there are around 12-14 topics throughout the semester. These topics contain a lot of basics in political science such as basic game theory in political science, democratic system, democratization, voting system, political censorship, resource curse etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Jean HONG has great teaching skills. She's good at generalizing the content and explain the most interesting/important part to us and it's really helpful to understand the political world and political science. She's serious in teaching and appears demanding, but she's actually really nice and kind to answer questions and solve our problems.
reviews.comment_grading:
My grade is fairly good. We are assessed by presentation, mid-term, final exam, final paper and also random attendance checking.
The topic of presentations is determined by the professor and she will allocate the groupmates for you. But she will ask for your preferences on topics in the first class.
Mid-term and final share similar pattern, non-cumulative, focus on the readings and lecture notes, one week for preparation is enough but of course it's better you can read the assigned reading week by week.
Paper is the most demanding, 2500 words, topic can be determined by ourselves. Consultation session is provided. You need to spend effort in order to impress the instructor.
All in all, as long as you pay enough effort in this course, the grading will reflect your hard work.
reviews.comment_workload: Refer to the grading.

reviews.author: oceannn
reviews.comment_content:
1. Orientation
2. Comparative Approaches
3. Comparative Methods
4. Democracy
5. Economic Explanations for Democracy
6. Cultural Explanations for Democracy
7. Dictatorship and Political Consequences
8. Political Parties
9. Interest Groups
10. Political Parties
11. Interest Groups
12. Government Systems
13. Democratic Systems and Political Consequences
14. Electoral Systems and Political Consequences
reviews.comment_teaching: James's lessons are engaging. He encourages students to participate in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Digital Poster and Video Presentation (group-based)  20%
Peer Review (group-based)  5%
Take-home Essays 1 & 2  60% (30% each)
Quizzes x 3  15% (5% each)

Attendance and Participation Bonus
(A maximum of 5 points will be awarded to students who contribute actively to class discussions. Attendance will be taken on an ad hoc basis.)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair. You do not have to memorize anything in this course as the quizzes are open-book.

reviews.author: FDR
reviews.comment_content: A relatively entry-level to the intermediate course on comparative politics & regimes. While the actual content isn't as intimidating as the course name suggests, some still require quite a bit of study (i.e. Game Theory, different electoral systems). If you do study hard, you'll be home with a much more academic and thorough understanding of the world of politics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent professor. She always makes sure that your answers are answered, and tries to make the supposedly tedious topic into an interesting one. There are real-life examples and her lectures are a pleasure to take. She's got a funny accent btw which makes things even more 'entertaining'.

Best part about this course is you can choose pretty much any topics for your final essay (of course it has to be related to the course, say you can't discuss why Biden fell on his way to the plane, probably), and you can have a consultation session with Prof Hong before starting it.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good on my part. Two exams and one essay, and that's pretty much it. I was slightly below mean in both exams, but still got within B range. Attendance is always checked.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost none. Just revision for exams and write the final essay.

reviews.author: Nano.
reviews.comment_content:
Research MethodsIs political science a science?  

The nation stateWhat is state?  What is nation?  What is sovereignty?  How does state differ from dynasty?

Democracy

Social Movement

Redistribution and Welfare Politics

Natural resources

Political Violence and Civil War
reviews.comment_teaching:
quite interesting
Provide lecture notes and readings (optional)
reviews.comment_grading:
Random counting attendance, need to send email for record.
No assignment and essay (cut)
Random assign groups and topics for the project and presentation. (After filling a survey form)
reviews.comment_workload:
Mid term
Project and presentation
Final exam (Open book)
Quite a lot of reading materials (Optional)

reviews.author: alexchw
reviews.title: Super good grade
reviews.comment_content: It is good for someone who knows nothing about politics as the content is easy to understand!
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Hong is very nice and she is willing to answer the question of students via email and after lesson.Her lecture slides are also detailed and include some information of readings which are easy to catch up. Prof. will answer question and give us some tips, so it is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading column
10% - Attendance and Participation
20% - Midterm examination
30% - Group presentation
40% - Final examination
I think the grade is super good, even better than the SOSC3410 (I have written the review of it as well) I only got 27.5/50 in mt (mean 32.8), i guess there was below around 0.75-1 s.d, i don't think i performed well in the final examination as well, but it turns out A- finally......
Totally no idea about the super good grading.
reviews.comment_workload: You may refer to the syllabus. I would say that the attendance is strict as the prof requires us to send her an email in the start of lesson as the way to check attendance. But everything will be alright if you try your best.

reviews.author: xxxxxx_
reviews.comment_content: The course content itself is pretty interesting and easy to understand once you catch on. However, there are a lot of things to memorize (i.e.: different systems of voting and whatnot).
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is nice, passionate, and willing to teach, but I found her powerpoint slides to be quite disorganized and difficult to follow. You really can't understand anything from just looking at the slides; she has to be there to explain it in person. For that reason, I didn't enjoy the class as much as I could have. The teacher does random checks of attendance, and is quite strict with it, so you do have to be aware of that.
reviews.comment_grading: This professor was especially kind when it came to grading, especially for this semester when there were many changes made to our academic year. Although it takes her a long time to grade, she was very generous with the final result. I didn't score very well in the midterm or the final, but still ended up with an A-.
reviews.comment_workload: I personally found the workload to be pretty manageable. There's not too much to be done so long as you keep up with the course content class by class, though it does pile up when you get to the midterm and final periods (there is a lot of content to memorize). The group project wasn't too stressful at all.

reviews.author: Diona
reviews.title: Interesting class, good prof and good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Basic politics knowledge,

Research Methods
State and Regime
Democracy
Autocracy
Democratization (and Autocratization)
Electoral System
Political Parties
Government System
Social Movement
Economic Growth
Redistribution and Welfare Politics
Poverty and Inequality
Natural resources
Political Violence and Civil War
Political Connection and Corruption
reviews.comment_teaching: Really nice prof.
reviews.comment_grading: she didnâ€™t release marks but my final grade is A. haha I attended every classes and studied 2 days before the the mt and final.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 essay 30%
1 mt 20% 1 final 20% ( mc true/false short questions)
1 group project 20%
Random attendance check 10%

Very light workload. Mt and final are very essay. If you attend all lessons, you will be okay.

reviews.author: HY Chan
reviews.title: A wonderful course for everyone
reviews.comment_content: The contents are quite comprehensive and I love the fact that I have a much better understanding of this topic after the course. But I think the content is a bit too easy for 3000 level. The only numerical part is game theory. If you study game theory before, it should be really really easy for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Hong is funny and nice and her teaching is wonderful. She explains the concepts clearly with an aid of abundant previous researches. She also cares about students' learning experience. I was not very into politics in the past. But after SOSC 3520, I feel like taking more politics related courses now. Unless you detest politics, you will like SOSC 3520.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is good. You will get good grade if you work hard on essay and pay attention in class. I did not read the essential readings and still got A at the end. So the key is understanding the lecture notes thoroughly and paying more effort on essay writing. Consultation session for essay writing conducted by prof was very helpful which could help you finalize your essay direction.
reviews.comment_workload: Midterm, final, presentation and a 2000-word essay. Revision wise, workload is not heavy since the content is quite easy. As a business school student, presentation is not difficult in my opinion. I believe most people would find essay harder. So start early.

reviews.author: bububuuss
reviews.comment_content:
comprehensive teaching in basic aspects of politics
not very difficult even if you are not very good in politics! the textbook will help to understand the topics
reviews.comment_teaching:
nice prof!!!! not very stressful
a relaxing environment
reviews.comment_grading:
good! when everything meet mean, i think you can get b or even above!

i did not expect a range without many political knowledge but i really got one
reviews.comment_workload:
2 exams(MCs plus short essay) ,one project, one discussion (gp work), quizzes for attendance
not very heavy, and prof will offer help if you want!

reviews.author: tsaidonodn
reviews.title: Fun class with good grade
reviews.comment_content: The content covers many new concepts, may be a little much for students without any prior knowledge (like me).
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good, the professor explains the concepts very clear. He is also quite humorous. There is a 10 minutes "tea break" in the middle of each class, which is great idea.
reviews.comment_grading:
got 1 SD above average in both midterm and final
mediocre score on group project
7/10 in participation
A- in the end
pretty surprised and satisfied
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload.
class note (about 600 words per person)
project (about 1500 words per person) (finished it within 1~2 days )

reviews.author: anonymous_
reviews.comment_content:
- 1 Group Project  (5 ppl in a group ~1000 word each)
- 1 simple 5 mins group presentation (separate from the group projects)
- 1 midterm (mostly MC questions with a few short questions)
- 1 final (mostly MC questions with a few short questions)
- Attendance and pop quiz
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Not all-the-time funny lecture given politics is boring
- James did put effort in teaching
- He is very passionate during lessons
- Very engaging when you consult him for the group assignment
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade is good if you are aiming for B range/A-
A+ would be super hard, maybe 1 or 2 people per semester
reviews.comment_workload:
No reading no assignment no essay
The lightest workload among all SOSC/HUMA 3000-level courses

reviews.author: HYC
reviews.title: A nice course
reviews.comment_content:
Some fundamental knowledge in politics be interest group and different kinds of regime including the authoritarian regimes .
Some lectures focuses on the relationship between the different part of the government such as the Congress .
reviews.comment_teaching:
A very nice professor and willing to answer the questions in class .
Students can have consultation about the group project .
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grade.Because it is a 3000 level course and I guess B range is normal for the students without any social science background.
reviews.comment_workload:
One group project and presentation.
Usually have supplementary readings for different topics (1-3 pages)

reviews.author: cocojojo
reviews.title: quite a gd course!
reviews.comment_content:
Group project (30%)
Test 1 (30%)
Test 2 (30%)
Country briefing (5%)
Pop quizzes (5%)

Basics about comparative politics
Political regimes
Political institutions
Political actors and processes
Political outcomes

quite interesting especially for those who loves politics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Loving the lesson. I want to investigate more on politics after the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: easy to get good grades cause the task isnt that difficult. if you are hardworking enough, you can get good grading easily.
reviews.comment_workload: quite a lot of stuff to recite. but if you are really really intersted in investigating in politics, it wouldnt be a tough task for you.

reviews.author: Benzqq
reviews.comment_content: A really refreshing course completely new perspective on politics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor makes the class so enlightening and enjoyable. Expect great times of relaxation and deep thinking in this course. And hug the professor hahaha.
reviews.comment_grading: Exams are pretty adequately written and graded. Prior to exam, the prof will help you review a little bit which is super helpful. Just put your efforts, you will see your result.
reviews.comment_workload: Fair workload. I should say small but it's such a great experience studying on regime type and development structure with my team buddies.

reviews.author: Fransis C
reviews.comment_content: The course is about comparative politics. Professor would talk about elections, inequality, parties and some other interesting topics. You can actually learn a lot from the election part. Game theories are the easiest part to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is cute and considerate. She's from South Korea.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not based on curve.
attendence
midterm
final
presentation
paper
Paper is very important. If you don't want to write paper, don't take this course.
reviews.comment_workload: You'd better read the essential readings, but it's not a must. However, you have to memorize detailed information from lecture notes. Paper is within 2500 words, not so easy to finish.
